selective.intro:
Aluminium and oxygen react to produce aluminium oxide.
4 Al + 3 O2 → 2 Al2O3
selective.question: How many kilograms of aluminium oxide are formed when 5.4 kg of aluminium react with excess oxygen?
selective.explanation:
The correct answer is: 10.2 kg. 4 moles of Al produces 2 moles of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. The mass of 4 Al is: 5400 grams. The relative atomic mass of Al is: 27 grams per mole. The number of moles is: 5400g ÷ 27g mol<sup>-1</sup> = 200mol. 
There are 100 moles of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> because every 4 moles of Al produces 2 moles of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. The relative atomic mass of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> is: 104 grams per mole. The mass of 2 Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> is: 104g mol<sup>-1</sup> × 100mol = 10400g.

selective.intro:
Calcium carbide and water react to produce ethyne and calcium hydroxide.
CaC2 + 2 H2O → C2H2 + Ca(OH)2
The volume of one mole of any gas is 24 dm3 at room temperature and pressure (r.t.p.).
selective.question: What is the volume of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> produced, at standard temperature and pressure, when 45 g of water reacts completely with calcium carbide?
selective.explanation:
The correct answer is: 30 dm<sup>3</sup>. The relative atomic mass of 2 H<sub>2</sub>O is: 2 × 18 g mol<sup>-1</sup> = 36 g mol<sup>-1</sup>. The number of moles of 2 H<sub>2</sub>O is: 45 g ÷ 36 g mol<sup>-1</sup> = 1.25 mol. 
There is 1.25 moles of every reactant. The volume of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> produced is: 1.25 mol × 24 dm<sup>3</sup> = 30 dm<sup>3</sup>.
